newsitem.title: USA: Entergy nuclear power is cost competitive.
newsitem.headline: Entergy nuclear power is cost competitive.

text.p: Entergy Corp's nuclear generated electricity is competitive and it can be competitive in a deregulated marketplace, chief nuclear officer Donald C. Hintz told security analysts Thursday.
"In Entergy's nuclear organization, we are controlling costs -- and producing power at costs that are competitive with other energy sources -- not just with other nuclear plants," Hintz said.
The good performance of Entergy's nuclear plants has positioned Energy to market its services as a manager of nuclear plants to other utility companies, Hintz said.
He noted Entergy signed a memorandum of understanding on July 31 to explore managing two New York Power Authority plants.

"Additionally, over the summer, three other nuclear utilities have expressed their interest in talking with Entergy about the future of the nuclear power business and the various scenarios that might evolve," Hintz said.

Entergy will also expand its "geographic footprint" by offering new services, using its competencies to finance long-term investments; and design, build and maintain distribution networks, John A. Brayman, executive vice president - business development, told the group.

Opportunities are being targeted in four general areas: energy management, illumination, and space conditioning; telecommunications and information services; broadband communications; and security and alarm monitoring, he said.
Wednesday the company announced a tentative agreement to acquire National Security Service, a security monitoring company.

Through investment in domestic and overseas power projects, Entergy has acquired a net ownership of an additional 1,300 megawatts of generating capacity and interests in distribution and transmission systems serving 1.4 million additional customers, the company pointed out.
